But now, when I read this back again, its like, these emotions and things we feel bad about is a matter of perspective and a different mindset.

To have a clear judgement and moral guidance, from good to bad, gave me a clear distinction and opinion about this story.

It's like looking at my past self, maturing or in other terms, getting better in handling this kind of things.

NTR sucks and its bad, but we must try to look at different point of views, to mature and to improve.

Meaning is derived from the subject's relation to the object. When the artist explains the meaning of something they made, the are invalidating a multitude of possible theories and interpretation. Great texts, such as most of the works in the western canon, are great because they allow for so many interesting interpretations. Of course I'm not saying that all interpretations are valid, or that all things in a work are "meaningful" (i.e., meaningful by most standards) I'm saying that theory has some validity or value if it has enough evidence from the text.  For example, my analysis for this work could be "it's all a dream", but I don't have any evidence from the text to support that.  You people should go and analyze art (and yes, this counts as art too).  Don't complain about things being "left up to interpretation" because that is one of the key points of art, to analyze and interpret.

The characters are also "neutral" in the sense that no character is truly good or bad.  The main character starts out fine, but becomes a weird sort of womanizer that eventual leaves his girlfriend (based on my interpretation on the ending, which I'll get to) and starts a seemingly better relationship (though it might just be an "okay" relationship).  The two main girls want to be with the [boy] MC but they still give in to their lust and still have sex with other men, though the MC doesn't seem to take this as a huge issue.  And boy oh boy, that ending.  It's left wonderfully vague by the artist and I think it fits best.  It doesn't give you a happy ending, nor does it give you a sad ending. If you take the ending by itself, you just get a neutral ending, where all 3 of the MC's start new relationships, and seem to grow up.  I'm not saying that this artist had this intention when creating it, but to be honest... who gives a shit what the author intended.  (next is last one i swear)

This work evokes the idea that Kurt Vonnegut had about "the shapes of stories" (go look up "vonnegut shape of stories" and there'll be clip of a lecture he gave) and how masterpieces like Hamlet have an almost "neutral story" in terms of the main character's luck.  I believe that this work successfully demonstrates the idea of a "neutral story".  Now you could argue there are little things here and there, but over all, given the events in context of the events afterwards, the main character has neutral luck.  He finds out that his clubmates are have orgies without him, and initially he is confused and a little sad but he begins to have sex with the women until he has having sex with all of them, so in a way he essentially became a part of the orgies.  Later he finds out his girlfriend is pregnant, which is good news, but that is balanced out by the fact that she agrees to joining the orgies, which sucks, but she said she refuses to do vaginal which ever so slightly makes it better.

Amazing story. The author uses the sex scenes to mask his take on human greed, lust, and envy. In a paradise of lust created by the club leader, everyone loses in the end ( yes including the leader as his group is implied to be disbanded ). This story is one of losing innocence and overcoming misfortune. 

The MC is the allegorical resemblance of all of us who think of the world as a place where work and persistence brings success. The MC learns through his journey that everything around him was fake and he spirals into rage, breaking all normalities and even having sex with his sister. This mirrors to the realization that modern life is not what we thought of it when we were younger, learning if how corrupting everything is.

Everyone loses as they are unable to feel love anymore, which explains why the MC and his childhood friend are exposed to have other relationships in the last pages.
